abstract.p: Andrew Wyeth's painting Christina's World will return to Farnsworth Art Museum in Rockland, Me, where it was first exhibited for first time in 50 years; will be on loan from Museum of Modern Art and will be seen in conjunction with exhibition on art of Wyeth's father, N C Wyeth, and son James Wyeth; photo; Yale University Art Gallery in New Haven will stage exhibit of political caricature from 16th century to modern times, The Body Politic: The Evolution of Political Satire in Print; photo; San Francisco Symphony and Dallas Symphony Orchestra begin European tours; six Indian movie stars, including Sanjay Dutt and Sushmita Sen, will appear at Nassau Coliseum in musical extravaganza, Wanted Alive (M)

block.p: Christina is going home. For the first time in 50 years Andrew Wyeth's painting ''Christina's World'' (1948) is returning to the Farnsworth Art Museum in Rockland, Me., where it was first exhibited. On an extended loan from the Museum of Modern Art from Saturday through Dec. 31, ''Christina's World'' will be seen in conjunction with an exhibition on the art of Andrew's father, N. C. Wyeth, and son James Wyeth. ''One Nation: Patriots and Pirates Portrayed by N. C. Wyeth and James Wyeth,''' also continues through Dec. 31.

Poking fun at politics is nothing new. Pegged to the first United States presidential election year of the third millennium, the exhibition opening tomorrow at the Yale University Art Gallery in New Haven traces the evolution of political caricature from the 16th century to modern times. In the beginning were the allegorical prints based on designs by Pieter Bruegel the Elder and Titian. Political caricature became a full-fledged genre in 18th-century England, and the exhibition includes works by Hogarth, James Gillray and Isaac Cruikshank from the golden age of English caricature. Other artists in ''The Body Politic: The Evolution of Political Satire in Print,'' which continues through Nov. 26, include Goya, Daumier, Thomas Nast, Red Grooms and Warhol.

Don't look for the San Francisco Symphony and the Dallas Symphony Orchestra in their usual haunts in the days to come. Joined by the pianists Martha Argerich and Helene Grimaud, Michael Tilson Thomas and the San Franciscans left yesterdayfor a 13-concert, 11-city European tour through Sept. 13. The Dallas Symphony, led by Andrew Litton, leaves on Saturday on a 10-concert European tour through Sept. 16.

When it comes to making movies and attracting audiences, India brooks little competition. Its film industry, popularly known as Bollywood, cranks out some 800 films a year and attracts an audience of hundreds of millions. At 8 on Saturday night six Bollywood stars, including Sanjay Dutt and Sushmita Sen, are to appear at the Nassau Coliseum in a musical extravaganza, ''Wanted Alive.''
